metadata.title: Onion-like nanospheres organized by carbon encapsulated few-layer MoS2 nanosheets with enhanced lithium storage performance

Onion-like nanospheres organized by carbon encapsulated few-layer MoS2 nanosheets with enhanced lithium storage performance
Jian-Gan Wanga,∗, Huanyan Liua, Rui Zhoua, Xingrui Liua, Bingqing Weia,b,∗∗
a State Key Laboratory of Solidification Processing, Center for Nano Energy Materials, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Northwestern Polytechnical University and Shaanxi Joint Lab of Graphene (NPU), Xi'an, 710072, China bDepartment of Mechanical Engineering, University of Delaware, Newark, DE19716, USA
H I G H L I G H T S
• Onion-like nanospheres of carbon encapsulated few-layer MoS2 nanosheets is prepared. • The nanocomposite delivers a specific capacity of 1119mAh g−1. • The hybrid electrode shows excellent rate and cycling performance.
G R A P H I C A L A B S T R A C T
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Molybdenum disulfide Nanosphere Li-ion batteries Anode Nanocomposite
A B S T R A C T
Two-dimensional MoS2 is a promising anode material for Li-ion batteries, but suffers from poor electrochemical activity and stability. Herein, a facile approach for the controlled synthesis of onion-like nanospheres organized by carbon encapsulated MoS2 nanosheets is developed through a simple polymerization and sulfidation/carbonation process. Mo-containing polyoxometalate is demonstrated to enable polymerization of polypyrrole accompanying with uniform encapsulation of Mo-nanoclusters. The hybrid precursor confines the growth of fewlayer MoS2 nanosheets (≤5 layers) into N-doped carbon framework, which is of great benefit in enhancing the electrical conductivity and structural integrity. As a result, the nanospherical MoS2@C hybrid electrode manifests high Li-ion storage capacity (1119mAh g−1 at 0.1 A g−1), excellent rate capability (616mAh g−1 at 2 A g−1), and long cycling stability. The substantial improvement is rationalized by fast electrode kinetics and great pseudocapacitive contribution. The present work may offer a powerful engineering strategy of MoS2@C nanomaterials for Li/Na-ion batteries and electrocatalysts.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The massive usage and depletion of fossil fuels have triggered worldwide concern on the energy crisis and its associated environmental problems [1,2]. The most promising solution is to develop
sustainable and renewable power sources [3–5]. In this regard, Li-ion batteries (LIBs) have received great attention in a myriad of applications from electronics to electrical vehicles owing to the favorable characteristics of high energy density, long cycle life, and no memory effect [6,7]. It is important to note that the current commercial graphite

anode is limited by a low theoretical specific capacity (i.e., 372mAh g−1) and slow Li-ion reaction kinetics, which cannot meet the everincreasing demand of high energy and power densities [8]. Accordingly, exploring new anode materials with a high specific capacity and fast reaction kinetics is extremely urgent in scientific and technological communities.
Two-dimensional (2D) transition-metal dichalcogenides have been recognized as attractive anode candidates of LIBs because the unique 2D structure could provide large layered nanochannels for fast Li-ion transport [9–11]. Among the established 2D materials, molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) is of immense research interest in this field [12,13]. However, MoS2 suffers from several critical obstacles in the way of practical implementation. First of all, the low electrical conductivity of MoS2 impedes rapid electron transfer for high rate power delivery. Second, MoS2 nanosheets are easy to restacking into bulk counterpart, which substantially results in reduced electrochemical activity. Third, the cycling stability of MoS2 is very poor because of its huge volume change upon Li-ion insertion/extraction and undesirable polysulfide dissolution and shuttle. To mitigate these issues, the most effective strategy is to hybridizing nanostructured MoS2 with conductive substrates. In particular, carbonaceous nanomaterials, such as graphene [14–19], carbon nanotubes [20,21], carbon nanofibers [22–24], and mesocarbons [25,26], have been massively investigated to fabricate MoS2/carbon nanocomposites, which have shown enhanced Li-ion storage properties. It is worth noting that the preparation of MoS2 nanosheets in most of the previous studies are based on hydrothermal routes. A literature survey indicates that it is difficult to control the MoS2 morphology, such as the layer thickness and spatial distribution, using this conventional method. In addition, the nanostructured MoS2 is generally hydrothermal growing on the substrate surface, which is in direct contact with the electrolyte and thus may cause structural degradation and more side reactions. Therefore, notwithstanding these established advances, it is highly desirable to develop a new design strategy for embedding MoS2 nanosheets into carbon substrate.
In this work, we report a facile synthesis approach for the controllable preparation of onion-like MoS2@C nanospheres with substantial improvement in Li-ion storage performance. Different from the previously-reported MoS2-based nanomaterials prepared by the hydrothermal method, our strategy starts with a room-temperature synthesis route using Mo-containing polyoxometalate as an oxidative initiator to produce nanospherical hybrid precursors consisting of polypyrrole (PPy)-encapsulated Mo-species. And consequently, ultrathin MoS2 nanosheets with no more than 5 layers are uniformly embedded into carbon network after a sulfidation and carbonization treatment, constructing unique onion-like configuration. The conductive nitrogen-doped carbon framework significantly promotes the electrochemical activity and stability of MoS2, thereby bestowing the MoS2@C nanocomposite with high specific capacity and excellent rate/ cycling performance.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials synthesis
sections.text:
All chemicals were received from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent. In a typical synthesis procedure, 2.6 g of phosphomolybdic acid (H3PMo12O40, PMO) and 250 μL of pyrrole monomers were dissolved into 100ml of deionized water and 20ml of ethanol to form solution A and B, respectively. Then the pyrrole solution B was added slowly to the solution A under magnetic stirring. The mixture was maintained for 12 h at room temperature to complete the reaction. The dark blue precipitate was collected by centrifugation, followed by rinse and drying. To obtain the MoS2@C sample, the as-collected PPy-Mo precursor and thiourea (upstream) powders were placed in a boat, which was transferred to a tube furnace. Sulfidation was carried out by heating the furnace to 300 °C at a ramping rate of 5 °C min−1 under the
protect of N2 flow and keeping at this temperature for 2 h. Subsequently, the temperature was increased to 800 °C and maintained for 1 h for carbonization. For comparison, pure MoS2 was synthesized by a hydrothermal method according to our previous report [22].

sections.heading: 2.2. Materials characterization
sections.text: The morphology of the products were observed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, FEI nanoSEM 450) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, FEI Tecnai G2 F30). The crystallographic structure of the products was identified by X-ray diffraction method (XRD, X'Pert PRO, Philips). Raman spectrum was collected on Renishaw inVia RM200 with an exciting laser wavelength of 532 nm. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on Mettle Toledo DSC/TGA 3 + from room temperature to 700 °C under air flow with a ramp rate of 10 °C min−1. N2 adsorption/desorption isotherm was obtained on Micromeritics ASAP2020 at liquid N2 temperature. The specific surface area was calculated by Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. X-ray photoelectron spectrum (XPS) was recorded on a Thermo Fisher Scientific, ESCALAB 250Xi with monochromatic Al Kα radiation. All XPS spectra were calibrated by C 1s line at 284.5 eV.

sections.heading: 2.3. Electrochemical measurements
sections.text: The Li-ion storage performance of the samples was evaluated using CR2016-type coin cell. The active materials were mixed with conductive carbon black and polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) by a weight ratio of 8:1:1 in an N-methylpyrrolidone (NMP) solvent. The resulting slurry was painted on a Cu foil with a spreader. After drying at 110 °C in a vacuum oven overnight, the working electrodes were obtained by punching the foil. The thickness of the electrode is about 30 μm and the mass loading of the active materials is about 1.6 mg cm−2. Coil cells were assembled in a glove box filled with high purity Ar gas. Li foils and Celgard 2400 membranes were used as the counter electrodes and separators, respectively. The electrolyte is 1M LiPF6 in a solvent mixture of 1:1 vol% ethylene carbonate (EC) and dimethyl carbonate (DMC). Cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves and electrochemical impedance spectrum (EIS) were measured on Solartron electrochemical workstation (1260 + 1287). Galvanostatic charge/discharge tests were carried out on Land BT2013A battery system.

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text:
Fig. 1a illustrates the typical synthetic route of onion-like MoS2@C nanospheres. It is well-known that transition-metal oxygen anionic species (i.e., polyoxometalate) are highly active in initiating polymerization of various organic monomers [27,28]. In the present work, Mo-containing polyoxometalate of PMO is employed as an oxidative initiator to polymerize pyrrole monomers, thereby forming a nanospherical hybrid precursor consisting of Mo-species distributed in the PPy matrix. The molecular dispersion of Mo-species in PPy matrix allows for the confinement of ultrafine MoS2 nanostructures and the generation of nitrogen-doped carbon structure derived from PPy. Therefore, the subsequent sulfidation and carbonization treatments enable the formation of few-layered MoS2 nanosheets embedded inside the carbon framework, constructing a unique onion-like configuration. The heterostructure organized by the conductive carbon-encapsulated few-layer MoS2 nanosheets is anticipated to accelerating electron transfer kinetics and immobilizing structural stability of MoS2 during lithiation/delithiation processes.
The morphology of the MoS2@C sample is characterized by SEM imaging. The panoramic view shown in Fig. 1b reveals that the MoS2@C is composed of homogeneously monodispersed nanospheres, which is identical to the PPy-Mo precursor (Fig. S1, supporting information). A closer observation of the nanospheres (Fig. 1c and d) exhibits an average diameter of about 100 nm and smooth surface. The
detailed microstructure is further imaged by TEM. Fig. 1e confirms the nanospherical morphology of the hybrid. Magnified TEM imaging of one nanosphere (Fig. 1f) clearly demonstrates that numerous fewlayered MoS2 nanosheets are evenly distributed and embedded within the carbon framework, displaying a unique onion-like configuration. The layer numbers of the MoS2 nanosheets can be determined from 1 to 4 from the high-resolution TEM (Fig. 1g). In addition, the lattice spacing of 0.65 nm corresponds well to the (002) interlayer distance of the crystalline MoS2. The BET specific surface area of the MoS2@C nanostructure is as large as 21.2m2 g−1 (Fig. S2). For comparison, the pure flower-like MoS2 sample was prepared by a typical hydrothermal method (Fig. S3).
The phase structural information of the as-prepared samples is examined by XRD and Raman methods. As shown in Fig. 2a, both samples display the characteristic diffraction peaks that can be readily assigned to the crystal planes of 2HeMoS2 phase (JCPDS #75–1539) [29,30]. No additional peaks are detected, indicating the high purity of the samples. The presence of carbon component is clarified by Raman spectra (Fig. 2b) owing to its Raman-active nature. There are two broad Raman bands at 1340 and 1582 cm−1 exclusively for the hybrid sample, corresponding to the defect-induced D band and graphitic-induced G band of carbon structure [31,32]. The high IG/ID intensity ratio of 1.03 suggests a high degree of graphitization of the carbon framework, which is beneficial in enhancing the electrical conductivity [33,34]. The carbon content is estimated to be 18.9 wt.% from the TGA curves (Fig. S4). Moreover, the fundamental sharp Raman peaks at around
378.1 and 400.6 cm−1 are attributable to the in-plane E12g and out-ofplane A1g modes of the hexagonal MoS2 crystals, respectively [30]. It is well-documented that the peak separation (Δk) increases with the increase in the layer number of MoS2 nanosheets [35,36]. Notably, the Δk of the MoS2@C hybrid (22.5 cm)−1 is much smaller than that of the control MoS2 sample (26.7 cm−1) and comparable to the reported 2- layered MoS2 (22.4–23.2 cm−1) [36]. The small Δk value indicates that the majority of MoS2 nanosheets are of 1–3 layers in thickness, which agrees well with the TEM observation.
XPS technique was used to investigate the surface composition and chemical states of the MoS2@C hybrid. The survey scan XPS spectrum (Fig. 3a) exhibits the dominant signals of the Mo, S, C, N, and O elements. The core-level spectrum of Mo 3d (Fig. 3b) can be deconvoluted into Mo4+ 3d5/2 at 229.1 eV, Mo4+ 3d3/2 at 232.3 eV, and Mo6+ at 235.5 eV [37]. The presence of Mo6+ is resulting from surface oxidation of MoS2 into MoO3. The core-level S 2p spectrum (Fig. 3c) is fitted by S 2p1/2 at 163.2 eV and S 2p3/2 at 161.9 eV, indicative of the S2− species of MoS2 [38]. The high-resolution C 1s spectrum (Fig. 3d) is composed of a prominent component at 284.5 eV and two peaks at 286.2 and 288.6 eV, representing sp2 CeC/C]C, CeO/CeN, and C]O bonds, respectively [14,31]. All these physicochemical characterizations demonstrate the successful formation of the hybrid MoS2@C nanospheres.
Electrochemical evaluation. The Li-ion storage mechanism of the MoS2@C hybrid is first investigated by the CV measurement. Fig. 4a and Fig S5a shows the initial five CV curves of the hybrid electrode and pure MoS2 electrode at a scan rate of 0.1 mV s−1, respectively. In the
first cathodic cycle, the peak at around 1.52 V is associated with the insertion of Li+ into the MoS2 interlayers to form LixMoS2 (i.e., xLi+ + MoS2 + xe−→ LixMoS2) [39–41]. The second peak at 0.93 V is ascribed to the formation of solid-electrolyte-interface (SEI) films caused by electrolyte decomposition. The third cathodic peak at 0.45 V
belongs to the conversion reaction of Li+ and LixMoS2 (i.e., (4-x) Li+ + LixMoS2 + (4-x)e−→ 2Li2S + Mo). From the second and subsequent cycles, the main cathodic peak at 1.86 V and the weak peak at 1.08 V are ascribed to the reduction of sulfur (i.e., 2Li+ + S + 2e−→ Li2S) and the reduction reaction of MoS2, respectively [17,26]. In the reverse scans, one strong anodic peak appears at 2.25 V, corresponding to the oxidation of Li2S to sulfur, while the small peak at 1.67 V is resulting from the partial oxidation of metallic Mo to MoS2. It is worthy to note that the Li-ion storage mechanisms of MoS2@C, after the first cycle, primarily come from the reversible redox reactions of sulfur at 2.25/1.86 V, which is consistent with the literature. Moreover, the enveloped redox peak area shows a slight increase upon initial cycling and almost overlaps after the third cycle, indicating the MoS2@C electrode has an activation process and excellent electrochemical stability and reversibility afterwards. Moreover, the peak intensity of the conversion reaction of MoS2 is much lower than that of the pure MoS2. The main reason may be ascribed to the enhanced electronic conductivity of the MoS@C hybrid, which could facilitate the reaction kinetics for direct oxidation of Li2S into sulfur. In addition, it is observed that the redox peaks related to sulfur are different from the typical twostep reactions of conventional sulfur cathode, indicating nanoscaled confinement of small-molecular sulfur in the carbon framework [42,43].
Fig. 4b and Fig S5b display the galvanostatic charge/discharge profiles of the MoS2@C hybrid and the pure MoS2 electrodes at different cycles, respectively. The voltage plateaus in Fig. 4b complies well with the redox couples described in the above CV analysis. The initial discharge and charge specific capacities of the MoS2@C electrode are 1344 and 1008mAh g−1, respectively, corresponding to an initial Coulombic efficiency as high as 75%. Both the reversible (charge) capacity and the initial Coulombic efficiency are much larger than that of the control MoS2 electrode (706mAh g−1 and 56.5%). Additionally, the specific capacity in the voltage range of 1.6–3.0 V (∼280mAh g−1) can be normalized to be about 1400mAh g−1 based on sulfur, suggesting a high electrochemical utilization of the active sulfur (theoretical value: 1675mAh g−1). The cycling performance is presented in Fig. 4c. Notably, the hybrid electrode delivers a high reversible capacity of
1119mAh g−1 after 100 cycles with an enhanced Coulombic efficiency of almost 100%, revealing outstanding cycling stability. The increased capacity can be rationalized by the electrode activation process (confirmed by the CV curves) and the formation of reversible gel-like polymeric films on the electrode [44]. In sharp contrast, the pure MoS2 electrode shows a considerable capacity decay of 62% upon 100-cycling test.
Fig. S6 shows the charge/discharge curves of the MoS2@C electrode at different current densities. It is noted that the redox plateaus are clearly sustained even at the current rate of 2 A g−1, indicating that the conductive carbon enables a high-rate electrochemical activity of MoS2. Fig. 4d compares the rate capability of the two electrodes. Encouragingly, the hybrid electrode could maintains average reversible capacities of 1112, 1064, 983, 798, and 616mAh g−1 at the current densities of 0.1 (0.16), 0.2 (0.32), 0.5 (0.8), 1 (1.6), and 2 (3.2) A g−1 (mA cm−2), respectively, which are much better than the control
electrode. As the current rate is resumed back to 0.1 A g−1, the specific capacity is rapidly returned to a stable specific capacity of 1150mAh g−1. The Li-ion storage properties of the as-prepared MoS2@C nanospheres are superior or comparable to the previously-reported MoS2based materials, as summarized in Table S1. To further confirm the high-rate cycling stability of the MoS2@C electrode, another cell was examined at 2 A g−1 (3.2 mA cm−2) for 500 cycles. As shown in Fig. 4e, the hybrid electrode preserves a specific capacity retention of 530mAh g−1 (0.848mAh cm−2) after the 500-cycling test. The superior electrochemical properties of the hybrid electrode demonstrate that the carbon framework plays significant roles of promoting MoS2 activities (high specific capacity), creating stable SEI films (high initial Coulombic efficiency), increasing the electrical conductivity (excellent rate capability), and accommodating the volume change of MoS2 (long-term cycle life).
Kinetics and quantitative analysis. To better rationalize the high-
rate performance, the electrochemical kinetics of the nanospherical MoS2@C electrode is systematically analyzed. EIS measurement is first carried out to gain the resistive and diffusive behavior. As shown in Fig. 5a, both Nyquist spectra are composed of a depressed semicircle in the high-medium frequency range and a sloped line in the low frequency range, which represent charge transfer kinetics and mass diffusion processes, respectively. Notably, the charge transfer resistance (Rct) of the MoS2@C electrode (57Ω) is much smaller than that of pure MoS2 electrode (191Ω). In addition, Li-ion diffusion coefficient (DLi+) can also be estimated by the equation of DLi+= 0.5·R2·T2·n·T−4·F−4·A−2·C−2·σ−4, here, R, T, n, F, A, C, and σ correspond to the gas constant, the absolute temperature, the transfer number of electrons, the Faraday's constant, the surface area of the electrode, the concentration of Li+, and the Warburg coefficient of Z’∼ω−1/2 relationship (Fig. S7) [31,45]. The DLi+ of the MoS2@C electrode is calculated to be 4.14×10−13 cm2 s−1, which is about 5 times higher than that of the pure MoS2 electrode (8.21×10−14 cm2 s−1). The lower Rct in combination with the higher DLi+ of the MoS2@C electrode is of great benefit in boosting the highrate delivery.
CV curves are measured at various scan rates to quantitatively analyze the intrinsic charge storage behavior of the MoS2@C electrode. The CV profiles in the scan rate range of 0.1–1mV s−1 (Fig. 5b) are similar to each other. Generally, the current response (i) and the scan rate (v) comply with the typical relationship of i= avb, here, a and b are empirical parameters. It is well documented that the b-values of 0.5 and 1 reveal a semiinfinite linear diffusion-controlled process and a surfacecontrolled capacitive behavior, respectively [46–49]. By plotting log i versus log v (Fig. 5c), the b values of anodic (O) and cathodic (R) peaks are determined to be 0.68 and 1.02, respectively, indicating a prominent capacitive behavior of the MoS2@C electrode. According to the equation i= k1v + k2v1/2, the charge storage at a fixed scan rate contributed by capacitive (k1v) and the diffusion-controlled (k2v1/2) processes can be quantified separately [48–50]. Fig. S8 exemplifies the CV
profile for the capacitive current at the scan rate of 0.8mV s−1, in which the capacitive contribution is quantified to be as large as 75%. Fig. 5d summarizes the capacitive contribution of the MoS2@C electrode at various scan rates. The capacitive contribution increases from 60% to 79% as the scan rate increases from 0.1 to 1.0mV s−1, indicating the pseudocapacitive charge storage accounts for a large portion of the total capacity of the MoS2@C electrode.
The excellent Li-ion storage performance of the MoS2@C electrode can be attributed to the unique hybrid nanoarchitecture. First, the monodisperse nanospheres provide a large surface area for the electrolyte to easily access to active sites, thus enlarging the electrode/ electrolyte contact area for efficient energy storage. Second, the nanosized onion-like structure could reduce the ion/electron transport distance to boost the electrode reaction kinetics. Third, the nitrogen-doped carbon network builds highly conductive pathways for rapid electron transfer. Finally, the elastic carbon framework could immobilize the embedded MoS2 nanostructures to maintain the structural integrity.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text: In summary, monodisperse onion-like MoS2@C nanospheres have been successfully prepared via a rational polymerization and a subsequent sulfidation/carbonation process. The design approach renders few-layered MoS2 nanosheets (≤5 layers) to be homogeneously encapsulated into the nitrogen-doped carbon matrix. Benefited from the ultrathin MoS2 nanostructures and the highly conductive carbon framework, the MoS2@C hybrid electrode manifests a significant enhancement in Li-ion storage through improved electrode kinetics and pseudocapacitive contribution. The target electrode delivers a high reversible specific capacity of 1119mAh g−1, excellent rate performance, and long cycling endurance. Moreover, the present strategy will shed new insight on the preparation of desirable MoS2/C nanostructures for various energy storage and conversion technologies.
